figure_1.title: Figure 1.
figure_1.caption: Trial schematic for the language and color shape switching tasks.

figure_2.title: Figure 2.
figure_2.caption:
Distribution of error rates on switch trials and disfluencies in the nondominant language for decliners and controls
The bolded center line shows the median of all error rates per group. The outer lines of the square show the first quartile (bottom) and third quartile (top). The extended lines show the minimum and maximum values without outlier.

figure_3.title: Figure 3.
figure_3.caption: Receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves classifying participants as decliners versus controls.

claims.sentence: In the single-task blocks of the language task, bilinguals named numbers 1–9 in just one language, while in mixed-task blocks they switched languages based on a cue (see Figure 1).
The distribution of error rates on switch trials and RRFPs in the nondominant language for comparison, are shown in Figure 2.
See Figure 3 for ROC curves, and Table 4 for AUC values.
Correlations between the novel measures, demographic variables, and other tests that were sensitive to AD risk in the present sample are shown in Figure 4.

Additionally, the strongest correlation in Figure 4 was between Trails B time and errors on switch trials of the color-shape task (r = .91), which were also significantly correlated with age and education level (rs = .47 and −.64, respectively), and the Digit Symbol task (r = −.78).

Similarly, RRFPs in the nondominant language were sensitive and specific for discriminating decliners from controls but were not significantly correlated with any other measure shown in Figure 4 (ps ≥ .19).

However, the language switching task was less influenced by age and education level than nonlinguistic switching measures (including the color-shape task and Trail Making Test B), and it was relatively less correlated with existing neuropsychological tests than the color-shape task (see Figure 4).
